Applies to

Scala and Play Framework 2.1.0+

What to Do

Use only FIPS 140-2 compliant encryption algorithms with SSL.

In practice, this means using TLS -- i.e., using SSL 3.1 or higher.  SSL 3.0 and earlier versions have a weaker key derivation process than TLS and are therefore not FIPS 140-2 compliant.  (It is very important to protect all sensitive resources, even if SSL 3.0 has to be used, but TLS is preferable.)

Note: TLS 1.0 is known as SSL 3.1, TLS 1.1 is known as SSL 3.2, and TLS 1.2 is known as SSL 3.3.

Why

Using strong encryption algorithms with SSL helps reduce the risk of successful eavesdropping attacks and assures regulatory compliance.

When

Whenever possible, use only FIPS 140-2 compliant encryption algorithms with SSL.

How

To use strong SSL algorithms, configure the web application server to use TLS (i.e., SSL 3.1 and higher) and not SSL 3.0 or any earlier version of SSL. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different platforms. Please, refer to your web application server's documentation or technical support for detailed instructions on how to configure the server to use TLS.

Communication Security Guidelines

  • Encrypt Communication Links
  • Use SSL
  • Use SSL for All Sensitive Pages
  • Use SSL When Transmitting Credentials
  • Use Valid SSL Certificates
  • Use Only Strong SSL Algorithms
  • Do Not Cache Sensitive Data
  • Do Not Place Sensitive Data in Parameters

Communication Security Checklists

  • Communication Links are Encrypted
  • SSL Is Used
  • SSL Is Used for All Sensitive Pages
  • SSL is Used When Transmitting Credentials
  • Valid SSL Certificates Are Used
  • Only Strong SSL Algorithms Are Used
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Cached
  • Sensitive Data Is Not Placed in Parameters
